Posts.Content: chemo072 wrote: Anyone else queasy with rads?  The rads docs tell me I shouldn't be queasy as rad are to the chest wall and not the tummy, but I am.....  Let's see - I finished chemo in August, took a break, had rads Oct/Nov, (1 more to go!), started tamox 10/6, quit 11/06 because of nausea.  And here it is almost 2 weeks later and I'm still queasy much of the time. I thought perhaps it was other meds (e.g. ibuprofen for rads burn).  But this morning I haven't taken any meds yet, and I'm stil queasy.  My tummy is beginning to feel more and more like it did on chemo, and I'm wondering if maybe rads somehow "brings back" the chemo SE? How long does the chemo (A/C +taxol) take to really get out of our bodies anyways?   I'm wondering if my body was in the process of getting it out, detoxing, and then if the rads stopped that process?  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: nausea? does rads bring back chemo SE? chemo072 TenderIsOurMight

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2008 09:24AM chemo072 wrote: I'm enrolled in the CoPay Relief program of the Patient Advocate Foundation and it rocks.  If you have a small pharmacy who is willing to take the time to call your CoPay case manager and ask for pmts, the PAF will pay the pharmacy directly.  When your cash flow is desperately low, this is an enormous help. I believe that getting in requires calling first thing on the 1st day of the month and staying on the phone for up to 6 hours, but it's worth it.  It's a 1-800 #, so not to worry about 6 hours of phone bills. Here's more info. about various funding sources (scroll down to financial aid) that I accessed. Best wishes with it all!

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 06:58PM chemo072 wrote: Yes - I had such intense fatigue by Oct 06 that I called a friend that I was supposed to visit, in tears, because I was just too tired to imagine traveling.  I was dx in Mar 07.  I've read repeatedly through these boards and others that some women went in complaining of fatigue and were dismissed (I was given a series of antidepressants, which not surprisingly didn't help), only to say later "sometimes sick and tired really is SICK and TIRED."  In my case, I dumbly thought that cancer had been ruled out, because wouldn't that have shown up in a blood test??  Umm - NO!!  Naive me.  I wonder how many women experience fatigue and get blown off only to find out later that the reason for it is cancer?  In any case, thanks for your post - I was wondering about this very topic!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:12PM chemo072 wrote: Fairygodmother Foundation Again, not for cash. :(  "WISH GRANTING GUIDELINES .... Wish recipients must be an adult with a terminal illness. We define "adult" as 18 years of age or older. We define "terminal" as having less than one year to live. A medical form verifying the health status of the wish recipient must be completed by the treating physician. The wish must be from the wish recipient.The wish recipient must be able to communicate the wish and must be able to comprehend the wish experience. It must be the wish of the recipient. The wish must not be a surprise. As appealing as it may be to surprise the wish recipient with something they have always wanted, Fairygodmother Foundation does not participate in surprises. We do not want to risk violating the privacy of the wish recipient. The wish must be the wish recipient's one and only wish. The wish recipient must not have had a wish granted by any other wish-granting organization previously, and must not be currently working with another wish-granting organization. All participants of the wish must be immediate family members to the wish recipient. Fairygodmother Foundation defines "immediate family" as spouse or significant other, children under the age of 18 living in the same household; or mother, father, and siblings (brothers and sisters) under the age of 18 living in the same household. The wish must be safe. The nature of the wish must not present any danger to the wish recipient or any sponsored participants. This includes travel wishes which may be detrimental to one's health. The wish must be legal. The wish must not violate any laws. Travel wishes must take place within the continental United States. Fairygodmother Foundation cannot grant wishes for foreign travel, or for travel to Alaska, Hawaii, or Puerto Rico. The wish cannot be for cash, cars, RV rentals, real estate, home improvement, or assistance to pay bills (including medical expenses). All wishes are subject to approval by Fairygodmother Foundation. If you are interested in requesting an application, click here."

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 06:30PM chemo072 wrote: Bimmer, sources that helped me: Brenda Mehling Cancer Fund Cancercare Co-Pay Relief, PAF Healthwell Patient Access Network Others that I heard about:  The Pink Fund Sensational in Survival Jennifer Ireland Foundation If you can hold it together to make the phone calls or even just copy and paste the email you wrote above, I'd start with Brenda Mehling and see if they can help, as it's a private foundation.  Same with Jennifer Ireland - they may have more discretion.  For the Pink Fund, a social worker at your hospital has to contact them.  CancerCare is probably a slam dunk, but only $450 total. Healthwell, Patient Access Network and the CoPay relief fund of the Patient Advocate Foundation are all big foundations, but maybe some of them could help.  Links are on my blog. Also, your hospital or docs may know of a private foundation that could help.  I'll go looking for sources for metastatic cancer care for you.  Seems like if there are make-a-wish type options for women with mets that that could perhaps be turned into fiscal help.   SSDI sounds like a good option as well.  Also, my local county income tax forgave various fees.   re: fed taxes, maybe prep those now (or take it all to HR Block and let them do it) and file Jan 1 and get money back?  It's not that far away and it could help.  Or if you have paychecks coming in at all, to stop withholding fed. taxes.  Stopgap I know, but that's what you need right now.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:15PM chemo072 wrote: Dream Foundation Again, no cash.  But still, there might be something Diane could wish for that would ease her pain through pleasurable distraction of some sort...maybe...  "THE DREAM GRANTING PROGRAM The Dream Foundation grants final wishes to terminally ill adults. We focus on assisting other human beings in dying peacefully with a sense of resolution and completion. Ours is a non-traditional, pallliative form of healthcare, and we have proven that although there is no cure for the illnesses that afflict the lives of terminally ill adults, we can help by improving the quality of their lives in a way no medicine can. DREAM GUIDELINES The Dream Foundation grants wishes to adults over the age of 18 whose life expectancy is one year or less and whose limited resources leave them unable to manifest a dream for themselves. To request a dream, potential recipients complete a Dream Request Form, available online or from the Dream Foundation. Recipients are encouraged to make realistic choices that fulfill a wish from the heart. Please note that we CANNOT grant the following types of dreams: * Requests for cash, automobiles, property, home improvements or RV rentals * Requests for visas or travel outside the U.S. * Requests to provide legal assistance, medical treatments or equipment * Requests for someone with a chronic illness who is not in the last twelve months of life * Requests from anyone other than the terminally ill adult * Requests for those who are not residents of the United States To Request a Dream The easiest way to request a dream is to click the link below to our online dream application. The completed application must be mailed to Dream Foundation. Faxed applications will NOT be accepted. If you are requesting a dream for someone in hospice care, please click here All others, please download our online application: click here You will need Acrobat Reader to open the application form above, if you do not have this program you can download now. If you would like us to mail you an application please call us at 805-564-2131 or send us an E-MAIL REQUEST and include your full Name, Address, City, State, and Zip Code."
Posts.Title: Something else we all have to deal with. Bimmer AliceJean

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:53PM - edited Nov 23, 2007 08:01PM by chemo072 I hear ya!  I'm so sorry that you had such trouble.  If the Portland you're speaking of is in Oregon....when I was dx with breast cancer in March, we got so incredibly tired of fighting our HMO that my work ins. brokers switched us to a PPO.  I loved my PCP & breast surgeon at Kaiser (miss them both, lots actually), but switching to Providence has been a godsend.  I can even go out of network if I want, and get 2nd and 3rd opinions to my hearts content.  Plus the social workers at the Ruth J Spears breast center rock, while the ones at Kaiser - I'm sure they're good therapists -- but they had no knowledge of the financial aid resources available to me, and that was the help I needed.  I sometimes think that if I have time I'll go back and educate them.  But in general with Kaiser, I had to fight, connive, wheedle, sweet-talk, (and bribe with promises of starbucks lattes), call labs myself, everything I could think of to get the test results so that I could read them myself in a timely matter.  We even checked out the mammogram films etc. under the guise of taking them to EPIC - which we did - and then I kept them.  They're my records darn it.   Kaiser was wonderful for some things - for example, their pain mgmt program rocks, and they had both ayurvedic medicine and a pain mgmt hypnotherapist which are services I can't find to be covered by ins. outside of Kaiser. And their optometrists were top notch.  And I miss my cardiology doc there too, lots.  But for cancer care, I think it just takes more flexibility and more options for docs than an HMO can provide.Just my two cents. Though, to their credit, they did pay in full for a PET Scan and a bilateral MRI with 2 biopsies at EPIC.  Hope you have better luck at the teaching hospital, and I'm just shocked that your breast surgeon didn't go over the whole positive margins issue with you.  That seems like malpractice to me. Are you going to court??  BTW, even when I was with Kaiser, I did get a 2nd opinion outside of Kaiser, and that was how I found the breast surgeon within Kaiser that I absolutely loved.  Funny that no one within Kaiser could refer me to her, but when I pulled strings outside of Kaiser, I got in with her and it made all the difference in the world.  She actually operates out of Providence, which was news to me when I discovered her.   The thing about an HMO - the right hand doesn't always know what the left is doing.  And they don't know about all the resources available within the system.

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 07:05PM chemo072 wrote: Making memories foundation: Make a wish for metastatic breast cancer Perhaps they could arrange for food deliveries, and flowers, or some such.  They can't give cash, but maybe they can give things that would free up cash for you otherplaces (e.g. food, transportation) ********  "Application For A Wish Contact Making Memories Breast Cancer Foundation and request this application by way of an e-mail request, regular mail or call 503-829-8846. Upon request, we will send you a Making Memories Wish Application Packet in the mail. If you have any questions about the process, contact Anna Nelson, Wish Director, at 503-829-4486 or send email to wishdirector@makingmemories.org Complete and return the packet of information to: Making Memories Breast Cancer Foundation ATTENTION: Anna Orr, Wish Director 715 June Drive Molalla, OR 97038 Phone: 503-829-4866 Fax: 503-829-3871 E-Mail: wishdirector@makingmemories.org Please note that many Making Memories events and items are donated by individuals, companies and corporations who wish to "Make A Difference" in the lives of those suffering from this devastating disease. Your submission of a request gives the Making Memories Breast Cancer Foundation your PERMISSION to share that request, in its entirety, with potential wish grantors. Wishes are granted as donors are found. We are unable to grant wishes for: * Automobiles, RV's * Cash or property * Large animals such as horses, alpacas, llamas, etc. * Funds for college education(s) * Foreign travel * Disney Cruises * Funds for medical treatments/medical supplies/equipment * Funds for legal assistance/attorney fees * Funds for home remodeling, room additions, pools or spas * Surprise Wish Requests (The wish must be requested by the recipient) * Making Memories reserves the right to add additional items to this list * Exceptions may be made for Priority Wish Requests"

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2007 12:49AM chemo072 wrote: Here's another possible funding source - not sure if they just serve California though: www.breastcancerangels.org/ang...  "FOOD PROGRAM Breast Cancer Angels provides Gift Cards to the market of the clients choice, dollar amount depends on family size and need. Average is $250.00 per month. We average $16,000 per month for these needs. HOUSING NEEDS Breast Cancer Angels assists with emergency housing costs. We will pay the security deposit and first months rent to assist women who have become homeless due to breast cancer treatment. We are the only group that assists (up to $500 a month) with housing for women in treatment for long term metastatic breast cancer. CLOTHES AND OTHER NEEDS Breast Cancer Angels also provides Gift Cards to Wal-Mart or Target for the needs of children in the home. We do this throughout the year with more spent in the fall for back to school clothes and shoes, etc. and at Christmas for toys and other gifts. We spend over $12,000 a year on these items. MEDICAL CO-PAYS & COBRA COSTS We provide this aid as needed. We do not want to see women lose their insurance in the middle of treatment or not be able to get their prescriptions filled. HOME HEALTH CARE & FINAL EXPENSE We will pay for short term home health care when a client moves onto hospice and needs home health care. We have also assisted with final expenses."

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2007 09:37PM chemo072 wrote: Umm...morphine (sustained release 15 mg) was what did it for me.  Taxol pain was like getting beat up from the inside - really really awful.  I took dilaudid for breakthrough pain but it didn't work, it was the sustained release that finally provided blessed relief.  However, be forewarned - after 5 days on it the body becomes dependent, and getting off of it isn't so easy.  No free rides.

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2007 07:46PM chemo072 wrote: Bimmer - Greetings from Portland, Oregon.  I too know Olympia well, and Chehalis a bit. So sending big big hugs that feel completely inadequate to you and your wife.  Just wanted to say my heart is with you in this terrible time.... and I hope that you aren't doing this alone.  Family, friends, neighbors, hospice, those that can help should.  Someone needs to be there in the house with YOU, on a daily basis.  Because that needing sleep so desperately at 3 am?  You can only do so much of that and then it's more than one person can bear, and if your health is impacted too that's a problem.  I know you don't even care about that right now.  But my point: Take the help - if the doc. wants to visit, let him.  He may be able to help.  My family has had dark, dark times, and the worst part of it when we look back was that we didn't ask for help (and didn't get it).  For the most part we went it alone.  And it didn't have to be as bad as it was.   And even though you won't feel like it, eat.  And drink lots of water.  Take the best care of yourself you can given the circumstances.  And if you need help with food or getting food ask 1 person you know - just one call - and have them organize it.  Praying like crazy for you and Diane, Amanda

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 01:20AM chemo072 wrote: elsko - so sorry to welcome you to the club.  :( it happens to a lot of us....my experiences are on my blog. There's also a young survivors group in my city, and meeting face to face makes a huge difference.  For instance, when I was freaked out about getting a port, all I had to do was mention it and 5 women bared their port scars immediately.  Made it much, much easier to get mine.   You're lucky being in medical school, it means that you have an interest in medicine already, and being able to deal well with medical information makes a big difference, at least in my experience. How to get through, well, you do what you have to do to live to be a ripe old age :) get all the tests and screening you can make decisions at your own pace - yes, it is urgent to get treated, but a week or two delay here and there isn't the end of the world do what's right for YOU  have friends and or family come to appts with you, so that they can listen, because there's a certain amount of denial and lack of comprehension of info. that's natural  one day at a time, one hour at a time, one step at a time get the insurance and fiscal stuff lined up - my blog has a lot of info. on that for me, finances were a stretch i wasn't able to work much during chemo, some people do same for rads the people that you expect to be there for you may not be, but others will come out of the woodwork so ask for help widely asking for help was the hardest lesson...I think being single I'd learned to be really independent, and accepting help was HARD..but oh so necessary you can't go it alone i set up different sets of friends for every chemo appt, to stay for 2 - 4 days  - mostly those were friends from out of town i saved the in-town friends for the rest of the days it took me 10 days to recover from ea. chemo which left me 3 frantic days to get everything done before the next round eeks eat your favorite foods now and then don't touch them during chemo i think that i never want to see earl grey or pez again as long as i live BTW, pez are great to have in the mouth during port flushes (it makes the mouth taste icky) canned peaches were good during chemo what else, ask all the questions you want do you even have to go through chemo?  hope things go well and that this phase of your life will be a distant memory as you wrap up medical school and complete the rest of your dreams...

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 01:45AM chemo072 wrote: big hugs...deep breaths.... scared to death..yep, I remember that.  I took a lot of valium equivalents at first because that core panic is really intense.  the great thing about chemo meds and for me, my response to trauma, is that the memory of it all is a little hazy.  my body just didn't want to remember it...it was really an odd phenomenology.  what i do remember are the good times - friends and family that helped, when food actually tasted good, etc. let's see - my social worker and my cancer counselor were life savers, if you don't have a breast cancer social worker yet through your hospital, that would be my first step.  she pointed me towards the young survivor's group, and helped me get all my financial aid applications in.   warning - the first social worker I saw was USELESS.  so I had to find another one, and she was so great! treatment varies according to the type of cancer you have.  Do you know yet what type, stage, grade etc. you have? timeline for me: March - dx, tests and surgery May - Aug chemo Oct - Nov rads but now I think the type of chemo has changed and rads isn't needed for everyone what tests have you had so far?  how'd your biopsy go?

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2007 02:47AM chemo072 wrote: Lucky you to like your doc.  The whole aspect of choosing a surgeon was challenging for me. The first one wanted to take all of my lymph nodes, and I said, no thanks - sentinel node biopsy please, I'll see the next surgeon.  Who promised that she would take as few lymph nodes as possible, and she did.  And she was a super communicator and didn't fight me on anything.  We were on the same page and she was one step ahead.  Vs. bad doc who was inexperienced and argumentative.  For something so personal like surgery, it's so important to like your doc, and trust them, and it sounds like you do!

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 11:29AM chemo072 wrote: Hi Shells, I think the issue is high risk - if you can show that you are at high risk, either through family history or BRCA1or2 testing (which they'll only do if a) you have a family history of cancers or 2) you've had cancer), then there's an argument to be made for an MRI:  http://www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/testing/new_research/20070810.jsp?gclid=CKS26-KfyZICFQY_agodzwWMbA   "The American Cancer Society recommends that MRI screening be done annually in addition to mammography starting at age 30 for women at high risk," Saslow said in a telephone interview. "For the most part, these are women who have had either a genetic test or found a mutation (that puts them at high risk of developing breast cancer), there is a mutation in the family, or there is a strong enough family history that would lead you to think that the risk of having a mutation is pretty high," she added. Women who already have had breast cancer have only a moderate risk of a recurrence and are not necessarily candidates for MRI, Saslow said. The reason is that MRI is expensive -- $1,000 to $1,500 per scan -- and has a high rate of false positives, meaning it detects lesions that are harmless." I have an intense family history of cacner, I had a tumor show up on a mammogram, I was 39, and even my HMO, the most conservative of spenders, sent me for an MRI.  Which yielded 2 false positives and so I had 2 biopsies that thankfully turned out benign.  But the MRI image was crucial in my decision making to have a mastectomy - I could see not only the main tumor  (IDC) but the DCIS wrapped around it and scattershot throughout the whole breast. That all said, as part of my young survivors group, the rule we've all arrived at given many harrowing stories of being pushed off because we are "young" is - if it's lump, get a biopsy.    For young women, breast tissue can be dense and hard to see with a mammogram. U/S helps, but MRI shows everything.  If the biopsy is positive, then an MRI will more than likely be approved.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 11:15AM - edited Mar 5, 2008 11:16AM by chemo072 ummm....hold up a minute here...no need to make radical decisions until you have all the facts.  have you had the gene testing done (brca)? i know that place of diagnosis is panicky (i had a very similar tumor) and i just wanted the tumor out, but getting all the facts in hand is essential. also, if you're node negative, what about the oncotype dx test?  (it can help you decide on chemo) and what about a full body PET scan?  then you can see if there's potential cancer activity elsewhere..  and do you have a breast surgeon you like?  if not, maybe get a 2nd opinion....find one you like.

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2008 02:09AM chemo072 wrote: Well....let's see, there's considerable controversy over whether fibromyalgia is autoimmune or not, but in any case, in Jan 06 I was dxed with fibromyalgia due to extreme fatigue and over sensitivity to pain....dxed with bc in Mar 07, was told the tumor had to be growing for over 2 years at the least, which means I had cancer when I was dxed with fibro.  in any case, 5 weeks after chemo was over I felt AMAZING.  Better than I had for years - not overstimulated, I could do 10 things in a day, have a whole day instead of the 4-6 hour days I'd had for the past 2 yrs, etc. etc.  and then with rads and tamoxifen things went downhill.  But I think that if fibro or whatever was wrong with me was/is autoimmune, then it makes sense that chemo kicked it, and as the chemo and massive doses of steroids get farther and farther out of my system that the old aches/pains/fatigue of fibro. start back up.  As for me getting bc, yes, I do have an intense family history, but do not have the BRCA genes, and I was most unfortunately taking a growth hormone secretagogue (in a trial for fibro.) that likely caused the tumor to grow.  My growth hormone levels were, and are, rock bottom (IGF-1).

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2007 01:12PM chemo072 wrote: My feet started swelling with A/C, and then with taxol they PEELED. Uggh. It hurt, but the bright side is that my callouses were gone and the new skin was baby smooth.  I did have to go to a podiatrist to get help with caring for them.  But as soon as the taxol was done, the swelling went down.  I also took glucosamine powder by the scoop 3* per day.  And for the mouth sores - I put ice in my mouth during chemo (supposed to help) and rinsed with salt water every night.  Magic mouthwash helped too.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2007 01:02PM chemo072 wrote: NativeMainer - darnit all, that's what I was thinking too just yesterday. Blood pressure is consistently higher in the past week than it used to be 140/87 vs. my normal 110/60-something...  heart rate has been high for the past 3 weeks - when I go to my fitness class is starts out at 110 or so and then I can only exercise up to 125 so let's say my cardio workout is s-l-o-w, and I've had heart palpitations (NOT normal for me), and a racy pulse this past week, but was taking provigil (a stimulant) to combat rads exhaustion. I think that tomorrow at my last rads appt I will insist on a referral for an EKG. Also, I've talked to 2 nurses and 2 docs about various aspects of this already, with no movement.  A while back with my HMO I had a false (?) alarm with a BNP blood lab that was off the charts and was assigned a cardiologist, who ordered an echo that proved that my heart was just fine.  The lab result wasn't replicable the next day, so we assumed it as a lab error.  But the reason for this small story is that at my HMO I was assigned a cardiologist, and he was amazingly helpful - called me at home even, and his cardiology nurse was top notch.  With my PPO I don't have a cardiologist, because for whatever reason (probably the normal echo pre-chemo) I can't get my docs to take my cardio. concerns seriously....but I just have this feeling.  I asked for a post-chemo echo and my onc. said no.  That was however, in August.  So, how to be heard on this one??  I've tried.  Could call my primary care doc I suppose.  After a while I get so tired of being an advocate for myself. Have laid off the meds, sugar and caffeine this weekend and the whole heart palpitation thing got better.

Posts.Title: Tips for handling stress while waiting for test results phoenix54 phoenix54

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2007 09:50AM chemo072 wrote: debbib - a) numb is totally normal, as is crying continuously - there's a whole gamut of normal, consider yourself hugged (if that helps) and b) my cancer center counselors told me that women who process all those emotions as they go along do better in the long run - less shellshocked perhaps when they come out of treatment, better able to get on and enjoy life etc.  so if you do have a chance for those feelings to come up and get out, sit with it, stay with it, don't drown them out, let the feelings come - and this is from me, ms. crisis-mode-I-can-handle-it-all herself.  I've been the queen of distancing and numb for a very long time.  One foot in front of the other - except when it's me, when it's MY body, it's damn scary.  I think I cried every day for a long time. and phoenix54, yay- you slept!!  healing bodies need sleep and all the strength they can get. Oh, and one thing that really helped me when first diagnosed, every day I went on "go" mode all day and dealt with what came, and I did everything I could, and when I lay down at night, I "gave it up to god" - not to sound overly religious or preachy, but at night, I just had to let go of it all, give it up to a higher power and go ahead and feel like a little kid who had someone to take care of me and relax and sleep and let it all go.  And that conscious letting go helped me a lot.  best wishes women!  you can do this.  it does suck though.
Posts.Title: Tips for handling stress while waiting for test results phoenix54 phoenix54

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2007 10:06AM chemo072 wrote: Deb2 - I had a right mastectomy because there was extensive DCIS wrapped around my IDC.  + spots of DCIS other places in the breast.  I was told that having chemo prior to surgery could shrink the IDC but that it wouldn't get the DCIS, that that had to be cut out, and because there were multiple spots....I looked at the MRI all lit up across the breast with the surgeon and it was just obvious that mastectomy was the only rational choice.  Otherwise they would have had to scoop flesh out of several spots out of my breast and I would have been left deformed without the right to reconstruction.  (My plastic surgeon told me that with lumpectomy there is not the legislated right to reconstruction that mastectomy has.)  So I was terrified and sad to lose my breast, and hoping not to have chemo, so I did the mastectomy first. The mastectomy surgery included a sentinel node biopsy, and indeed cancer was found in 1 node.  1 bastard node.  Plus it burst - extranodal extension.  Hence all the hassle of chemo and radiation. If I had had just IDC and NO DCIS, I would have gone for chemo first, with the hope of preserving the breast.  And then lumpectomy + sentinel node biopsy. Not having a breast is a painful hassle.  And I haven't gone the reconstruction route because I just had rads and have to wait 6 months.  Women who have had what I had but were able to have lumpectomies, and then had chemo and rads - they're done with treatment now.  And I still have reconstruction to go, which is no easy path. Oh, also, at first I was told the IDC was 3 cm (it looked that way on screening) + DCIS was 5 cm.  It turned out that the IDC itself was 1.9 cm, and with 1 node, that put me into the stage 2 category.  Sorry for the small tome!  Hope I answered your question. Also, re: freaking out - I worry and wonder before I have info. because I think that question generation process is really important - we have a family theory that it's the question that we don't ask that will get us - hope that made sense! - but I don't really cross the freaking-out bridge until I have the data in hand that indeed I will need to cross that bridge.  One thing you might consider is to get the BRCA genetic testing process going, because if you end up BRCA positive that may (or may not) sway you to go the mastectomy route.   Personally, I think the least invasive surgery the better.  The body is never the same afterwards. Big hugs to you,  and to your sister - hope her's turns out b9!! Let us know how things go!
Posts.Title: Tips for handling stress while waiting for test results phoenix54 phoenix54

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2007 05:10PM - edited Nov 23, 2007 05:11PM by chemo072 One day at a time.  One hour at a time if need be.  And, first things first. Personally, what got me through was assembling a stellar medical team.  I spent my energy collecting data (all the tests I could get) and people, those friend and family who were willing to get in their with me to digest the medical data, and the medical professionals that were charged with keeping me alive.  If I didn't feel one was going to do the best possible job for me, I went on to the next.  For me, it was all about the team.  Breast surgeon (first order of business), oncologist (2nd order), breast cancer social worker (3rd, my finances were hard hit by this), cancer therapist (at the cancer center), gynecological oncologist, psychiatrist.  The pieces that you may have in place already: primary care provider, naturopath.  I found that my naturopath's recommendations to various docs were gold when it came down to it.  But then again my naturopath specializes in womens health.  A primary care provider who is worth her salt could provide the same referral.  Furthermore, those two helped get me in with the breast surgeon and oncologists that I finally went with.  It's all an insider who-knows-who sort of system, in both HMO and PPO land.  A call from me got me an appt in 4 weeks, a call from a doc to a doc got me an appt in 2 days.  Make friends with your good docs, ask for their help, and get the referrals you need.  And if a doc doesn't sit well with you gut-level wise, keep on looking.  I personally need to interview 3 docs in each specialty before I can make a decision, it's just how I am. Also, the friends and family who were too distraught to be helpful, they went on hold - or into diversionary but helpful strategies: organize food deliveries, organize housecleaning, but lordy oh lordy don't bother me while I'm trying to make medical decisions that may save me life.  They either help or they're out of here.  Anyways, good luck.  The few weeks after diagnosis were the most harrowing in my life.  I never knew from the time I woke up to the time I went to bed what the day was going to hold.  I lost 20 pounds all told. And, don't go to appts by yourself - take someone with you to take notes, because it's too much to absorb yourself. Take care and let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: Pathology report---NOT Good Amy1971 nancy01

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2007 03:06PM - edited Nov 20, 2007 03:08PM by chemo072 Thanks Native Mainer!  I did stay in the exam room yesterday.  My rads onc was already to be done with the exam, and I said, um, no, I still have a very important question.  So I asked my rads onc point blank about getting an EKG but he said that I didn't "fit the profile" to raise alarms (I got the sense that profile = young women?).  And moreso, he basically said that it wasn't a rads-induced set of symptoms, so exercised his right of first refusal for symptoms the way that oncologists do, and bounced me back to my medical oncologist.  Plus my blood pressure was much better 118/70.  And heart palpitations have decreased.  And weight went down.  So.... Off to learn about heart issues in young women and keep on keeping on on this issue.  Bottom line, I want a cardiologist, but feel like I'm banging my head against a wall... But thank you for your tips!  I will check into the patient advocacy options through my social worker after I exhaust conversations with my medical oncologist and primary care provider. Today however I'm dealing with radiation burn pain and that's my focus for the day.  Lots of protein, lots of liquids, and morphine seem to be the way of it today.  One day at a time....and this too shall pass....

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 11:52PM chemo072 wrote: sheesh...at 92 I might just skip the whole shenanigan myself.  I had the same stage of cancer, with 1 lymph node positive, and had a mastectomy with lymph node dissection, chemo and rads, and just now, 10 months later, I'm finally bouncing back.  And I'm 39.  If i were 92, I might not want to spend those 10 months in cancer treatment, but that's me. Plus anesthesia, surgery etc.  it's a serious risk.  (stroke, complications, etc.)  Does the tumor hurt your mom right now?  Mine didn't hurt until it was biopsied, and then it started hurting and didn't stop, and I couldn't wait to get it out.  I agree, maybe a mast. without the lymph node dissection would be ok - the mast took several weeks to recover from, but it was preferable to that tumor hurting.... sheesh, what a hard decision.   prayers and hugs for your mom,
